thread.title: Unionists and Loyalists Converge to Oppose DUP’s Power-Sharing Agreement
thread.title_full: Unionists and Loyalists Converge to Oppose DUP’s Power-Sharing Agreement

author: Wojciech Zylm
title: Unionists and Loyalists Converge to Oppose DUP’s Power-Sharing Agreement
text:
The Domino Effect: Russia-Ukraine Conflict and Europe's Natural Gas Crisis
Unionists and Loyalists Converge to Oppose DUP’s Power-Sharing Agreement
Unionists and loyalists recently convened in Moygashel Orange Hall in Co Tyrone, expressing their disapproval of the Democratic Unionist Party’s (DUP) agreement with the UK Government. The agreement, aimed at restoring the Stormont powersharing institutions, has been met with opposition despite being described by DUP leader Sir Jeffrey Donaldson as a move that effectively removes the trading border for goods moving from Great Britain to Northern Ireland.
Key Attendance and Voiced Concerns
The gathering saw the presence of around 120 individuals, including notable figures such as Traditional Unionist Voice (TUV) leader Jim Allister, loyalist activist Jamie Bryson, and former DUP minister Jim Wells. Despite Donaldson’s assurance, Bryson argued that the Irish Sea border remains in full force and Northern Ireland continues to be subject to EU laws that they can’t alter. He criticized the DUP members who he claimed will be responsible for implementing the Northern Ireland Protocol and maintaining the border posts, which he views as a detriment to the Union.
Internal Division and Struggle Over Principles
The meeting served as a potent testament to the internal division among unionists and the struggle over principles versus pragmatic politics in the context of the Northern Ireland Protocol and its implications for the region. The new trade rules, aimed at alleviating the DUP opposition to the Irish Sea border and restoring power sharing in Northern Ireland, promise to remove routine checks on goods from Great Britain destined for Northern Ireland and bolster the Stormont brake that offers oversight to EU laws. However, opposition to the deal from some Westminster MPs and concerns within the DUP about potential defections to the hardline Traditional Unionist Voice persist.
Fast-Tracking Legislative Measures and Differing Opinions
The government is fast-tracking legislative measures through Westminster to cement the deal and pave the way for the recall of the Stormont assembly. The Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) has ended its boycott of power-sharing institutions, and the Northern Ireland Assembly is set to sit on Saturday. Despite this progress, there are differing opinions within the DUP regarding the deal, with some members expressing opposition, leading to tension within the party regarding the agreement negotiated by Sir Jeffrey Donaldson.
